 Peaceful Marches in Northern Ireland 
 By REUTERS
 BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12 (Reuters) - Protestants paraded through towns across religiously divided Northern Ireland in commemorative marches on Wednesday with no repeat of last year's violent clashes, allowing the army to stay off the streets for the first time since 1970.
 
 The annual marches, celebrating a centuries-old military victory but viewed by Roman Catholics as provocative displays of triumphalism, began as smoke from overnight bonfires and fireworks gave way to the clamor of pipes and drums.
 
 But even as Protestant Orangemen and their bands returned home through the traditionally tense Ardoyne area of northern Belfast, things remained relatively calm.
 
 A confrontation was avoided as, for the first time, march supporters went home on buses instead of accompanying their bands through an area that had been a flash point for disputes between neighboring Catholic and Protestant communities.
 
 Last year Catholic protesters hurled gas bombs and bricks at the police after a July 12 march through their area. In September, Protestants attacked the police during weeks of rioting after a parade was rerouted away from a Catholic area.
